info.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued January 04 at 5:02PM EST by NWS Boston
info.description: ...THE WINTER/SPRING FLOOD POTENTIAL HAS EXPIRED... The winter/spring freshwater flood potential is above normal across most of southern New England, but is near normal on Cape Cod and the Islands. The threat of flooding due to ice jams is below normal for early January. For a graphical depiction of this outlook, go to: http://www.weather.gov/nerfc/springfloodpotential This is the first winter/spring flood potential outlook of the 2024 season. This outlook is based on current and forecast conditions including temperatures, precipitation, snow cover, snow water content, river flows, soil moisture, and ice coverage. ...RECENT TEMPERATURES AND PRECIPITATION... December, 2023 was a warm and wet month in southern New England. Temperatures averaged 3 to 6 degrees above normal for the month. It was the second warmest December on record in Hartford and Worcester and the third warmest December on record in Boston and Providence. Precipitation averaged 1 to 4 inches above normal, but was as much as 5 to 6 inches above normal from parts of Connecticut into northwest Rhode Island and interior northeast Massachusetts. It was drier on Cape Cod and the Islands where precipitation totals were 1 to 2 inches below normal for December. ...OBSERVED SNOW DEPTHS AND SNOW WATER CONTENT... The ground is currently bare with little or no snow cover in southern New England. This is below normal for early January. ...SOIL MOISTURE, RIVER FLOWS, AND GROUND WATER CONDITIONS... Soil moisture was well above normal. The wettest conditions were found in Connecticut, Rhode Island, and in western, central, and interior eastern Massachusetts. Streamflows were above normal, except were near to below normal across parts of Cape Cod. The highest streamflows were found in northeast Massachusetts along the Sudbury, Charles, and Concord Rivers. River ice was non existent. Groundwater levels were mostly above normal, but were near normal from far southern Rhode Island into extreme southeastern Massachusetts, and were below normal on Marthas Vineyard, Nantucket, and the outer portion of Cape Cod. Nantucket reported its lowest median groundwater level in its 40 year period of record to begin January. Edgartown reported close to its lowest median groundwater level on record for early January in its 43 year period of record. Wellfleet reported its lowest median record for early January in its 59 year period of record. ...TEMPERATURE AND PRECIPITATION OUTLOOK... An active weather pattern looks to continue for the next few weeks. The first storm system Sunday should bring accumulating snow to much of southern New England, then a warmer storm around the middle of next week could bring flooding rain in addition to runoff from melting snow. Over the next seven days, precipitation should average 2 to 4 inches. Looking farther ahead, odds favor a continuation of the warm and wet weather pattern through the end of January. ...SUMMARY... The winter/spring flood outlook for freshwater flooding is above normal in southern New England, except near normal on Cape Cod and the Islands. The overall weather pattern has led to above normal precipitation and temperatures across most of the region except on Cape Cod and the Islands where conditions have been drier than normal. An active weather pattern is expected to continue for the next couple of weeks, along with above average temperatures, which favors an increased potential for flooding. Flooding rain can occur any time during the year. The Graphical Hazardous Weather Outlook can provide a heads-up for excessive rainfall over the next five days: https://www.weather.gov/erh/ghwo?wfo=box The next Winter/Spring Flood Potential Outlook will be issued on Thursday, January 18.
